Hypersensitivity type I:

{{c1::IgE}} anti-bodies binds to the allergen, IgE corss links allergen with mast cell by binding onto the {{c1::Fc}} receptor.  The mast cell releases {{c1::histamine}} and eicanosoids such as {{c1::Lymphotoxins}} and {{c1::Prostoglandins}}

This reaction is called {{c1::degranulation}}

Histamine

Basic {{c1::amine}}
Stored in {{c1::mast}} cell granules
 Acts on specific histamine receptors H1, H2.... which are {{c1::G protein couples}} receptors

 H1 receptors present on
-{{c1::Bronchial}} smooth muscle – contraction
- {{c1::Endothelial}} cells – vasodilatation & vascular permeability
- {{c1::Vomiting}} centres in brain

Hypersensitivity type I reactions

Anaphylactic or immediate {{c::1hypersensitivity}} reaction
Develops only in genetically susceptible individuals
Mediated by allergen-specific {{c1::IgE}} antibodies
Central role of local histamine release in mild allergic reactions

Increased capillary permeability which causes {{c1::Wheal}} and {{c1::urticarial (hives)}}

Vasodilatation which causes {{c1::Erythema}}

Itch caused by {{c1::Sensory nerve irritation}}

Anaphylaxis: Clinical presentation 

{{c1::5-60}} minutes after exposure to allergen

{{c1::Urticaria}} and {{c1::angioedema}} due to Capillary leakage of plasma

Bronchospasm causing wheezing due to {{c1::Histamine}}-induced {{c1::bronchoconstriction}}

{{c1::Hypo}}tension and CV collapse due to {{c1::Hypo}}volemia, myocardial depression

Vomiting, diarrhea

Limitation due to narrow bronchi

In asthma, the airflow limitation arises as a result of the {{c1::bronchi}} being too narrow.
It is felt mainly at {{c1::exhalation}} as the positive pressure in the chest cavity when the {{c1::diaphragm}} and the {{c1::intercostal muscles}} relax constricts the {{c1::bronchii}} even further.

Lungs full and diaphragm flattened

Exhalation much slower in asthma

Causes of asthma
1. Allergic effect: {{c1::Mast}} cells, that release {{c1::histamine}} which constrict bronchial smooth muscle cells.

2. Neurological cause:{{c1::Vagus}} nerve acts on bronchial smpoth muscle cells through the neurotransmitter {{c1::Ach}}

FEV1 stands for {{c1::forced expiratory volume in 1second}}

During an asthma attack the FEV1 can decrease to as low as {{c1::75%}} (% of normal fev1)

Phase 1 asthma attack, Mast cell releasing histamine or Vagus nerve problem

Phase 2: CHronic {{c1::inflammation}}: Mast cells, eosinophils, neutrophils etc. infiltrate the bronchial {{c1::submucosa}} and {{c1::lamina propria}} which narrows the airway even more.
CD4+ T lymphocytes contribute to the inflammation

Cytotoxic Drugs, Radiation & other GI irritants release 5-HT from the {{c1::enterochromaffin}} cells 
 Stimulation of the {{c::15-HT3}} Receptors present on vagal afferents

Vestibular Irritation:
-The vestibular apparatus generates impulses when body is rotated or {{c1::equilibrium}} is disturbed or when {{c1::ototoxic}} drugs act. 
-These impulses reach the vomiting centre mainly relayed by the {{c1::M}} and the {{c1::H1}} receptors. 
-Various sensory stimuli such as bad odour, ghastly sight, severe pain as well as fear cause {{c1::nausea}} and vomiting by direct stimulation of higher centres
CTZ=Chemoceptor trigger zone

Vomiting Mediators and Receptors
5-HT: an important mediator involved in such signals, many other mediators and peptides are also involved. 

The CTZ expresses a variety of receptors e.g. Histamine H{{c1::1}} , Dopamine D{{c1::2}} , Cholinergic M, Opioid u and the Serotonin 5-HT{{c1::3}} receptors, through which the emetic signals are relayed.

Ascending pain pathway:

The painful stimulus is picked up by {{c1::C nociceptor}} and {{c1::A delta nociceptor}} (types of receptor)

The nerve enters the spinal cord in the {{c1::dorsal horn}}
It then decussates and ascends in the {{c1::spinothalamic}} tract

It passes through the {{c1::brainstem}} and {{c1::midbrain}} before synapsing at the {{c1::VP}} or {{c1::IL}} nuclei of the thalamus.

The pathway then divides into 3 pathways, leading to the {{c1::somatosensory cortex}},{{c1::cingulate cortex}} and {{c1::limbic system}}

Insulin:
{{c1::Peptide}} hormone
Synthesised, packaged and released from {{c1::pancreatic islets - β-cells}}.
Glucose Dependent Secretion

As it is a peptide hormone it cannot be {{c1::orally}} administered

Endogenous insulin is released into {{c1::portal}} circulation
Synthetic insulin is released into {{c1::systemic}} circulation

Proinsulin consists of an a,b and c chain
In insulin {{c1::a}} and {{c1::b}} chains are connected through {{c1::s=s}}bonds and the {{c1::c}} chain is cleaved

Therefore, what is a good indicator that patient taking synthetic insulin is starting to make their own insulin again?{{c1::the c chain}}

Endogenous Insulin Secretion:
Secreted into {{c1::portal circulation}}
{{c1::60}}% undergoes hepatic 1st pass metabolism

Step 1: Glucose enter {{c1::pancreatic}} cell through {{c1::GLUT 2}} channels.

Step 2: Glucose is broken down to {{c1::Glucose-6-Phosphate}} by {{c1::glucokinase}}(enzyme)

Step 3: ATP is formed through metabolism

Step 4: ATP opens {{c1::potassium}} channels

Step 5: The depolarization of the cell caused by the opening of {{c1::k}} channels, opens {{c1::Calcium}} channels.

Step 6: The influx of {{c1::calcium}} causes insulin to be released

In brief:

{{c1::Glucagon}} inhibits its release.

Etiology of Thyrotoxicosis

Definitions
Graves’ Thyrotoxicosis  {{c1:: immune system disorder that results in the overproduction of thyroid hormones}}
Toxic Adenoma {{c1::This occurs when a single nodule (or lump) grows on the thyroid gland causing it to become enlarged and produce excess thyroid hormones.}}
Toxic Multinodular Goitre {{c1::one or more nodules (typically benign growths) in the thyroid gland that make thyroid hormone without responding to the signal to keep thyroid hormone balanced.}}
Inflammatory thyroiditis {{c1::swelling (inflammation) of the thyroid gland. It causes either unusually high or low levels of thyroid hormones in the blood}}
Hashitoxicosis Factitious / Over-replaced LT4 {{c1:: transient hyperthyroidism caused by inflammation associated with Hashimoto's thyroiditis disturbing the thyroid follicles, resulting in excess release of thyroid hormone.}}
Drug Induced 
Post-partum Thyroiditis{{c1::post pregnancy}}

The Somatic Mutation theory

Essentially cancer is a result of many {{c1::mutations }} over time working together to change the {{c1::function}} of the cell, in many cancer patient there is also mutations within the {{c1::DNA repair mechanisms}} of the cell.

Cancer causes the {{c1::proliferation}} of cells where and when they should not
Cancers are “clonal”, meaning: {{c1::arising from a single aberrant cell}}
This does not mean that tumours are a homogeneous population of cells
The genomes of cancer cells are {{c1::unstable}}
As tumour cells proliferate, they acquire more {{c1::mutations}}
Tumour “{{c1::evolves}}” as its environment imposes selective pressures

Why is cancer among the older population at a higher rate thna the younger population? {{c1::Because the mutations aise from divisions, the more divisions you undergo the bigger chance of cancer}}

Cancer is a {{c1::multi-stage}} process

It can take many {{c1::years}} and multiple {{c1::mutations}} for malignancy to tkae place

Current models suggest that genome instability must result in {{c1::mutations that subvert particular cellular processes in order for a cancer to develop}}


Progression from normality to {{c1::malignancy}} requires the acquisition of various different capabilities or characteristics that cooperate to cause cancer. 

While no one change is sufficient to cause cancer, these changes are necessary for malignant {{c1::transformation}} and also for maintenance of the {{c1::malignant state}}. 

So what capabilities/characteristics that cancer requires are targeted by anti-cancer drugs?{{c1::ideally all of them}}

{{c1::75}}% of breast cancers are positive for the Oestrogen receptor (ER+).

Means Tumour is Reliant On ER Signalling to Proliferate and Survive

The oestrogen receptor is initially inactive in the {{c1::cytoplasm}} of the cell.

What type of oestrogen binds to the oestrogen receptor?
{{c1::E2, also known as Oestradiol}}

The receptor then {{c1::dimerizes}} and translocates to the {{c1::nucleus}}

What does it bind in the nucleus?
{{c1::to the oestrogen response element which is a ligand activated transcription factor, specifically activating function 1 (AF1) and 2 (AF2)}}

THE DRUGS THAT EFFECT THE OESTROGEN RECPTORS

The SERMs (SELECTIVE ESTROGEN RECEPTOR MODULATORS)

MoA: {{c1::partial agonists}} of the ER that interfere with the signalling that make it more likely for {{c1::pro-apoptotic}} signals to be expressed.

{{c1::tamoxifen}} and {{c1::Toremifene}} are SERMs used for Breast cancer

Clomiphene is used for {{c1::(Female infertility)}}

Bazedoxifene is on Clinical trial for {{c1::osteoporosis)}}

Ospemifene is on Clinical trial for {{c1::vaginal atrophy & dryness)}}

The SERDs (SELECTIVE OESTROGEN RECEPTOR DOWN REGULATORS)

MoA: Pure ER {{c1::antagonist}} binds to ER and prevents {{c1::dimerization}} and increases ER degradation by use of {{c1::proteases}}

The ONLY SERD that is approved is {{c1::Fulvestrant}}

Approved for {{c1::post menopausal}} women with ER+ tumours and metastatic tumours {{c1::refractory}} to other anti-
oestrogen therapy

Non-Steroidal Inhibitors: {{c1::Letrozole, ANASTROZOLE}}

All-Trans-Retinoic Acid

What is used to treat? {{c1::Acute promyelocytic leukemia}}

How is the MoA of the disease? . {{c1::The PML gene on Chromosome 15 is fused to the RARa gene on Chromosome 17 to produce a PML-RARa fusion protein that inhibits myelocytic differentiation.}}{{c1::}}

{{c1::If you give a high enough dose, it will outnumber the faulty gene expression and thus forcing the cancer cell to differentiate}}

T/F
One activated oncogene is not enough to cause cancer {{c1::t}}
An activated TSG causes cancer {{c1::f, the opposite}}
An oncogene needs to be constantly active to cause cancer {{c1::t}}

The Philadelphia Chromosome

Caused by a translocation between chromasomes 9 and 22 which causes the oncogenic kinase {{c1::ABL}} to attach to {{c1::BCR}}
Which causes the tyrosine kinase to be constituitively active.

This kinase can phosphorylate certain proteins which activates certain oncogenic pathways such as {{c1::Ras, PI3-kinase, Jak-STAT}}(3)
And certain oncogenic transcription factors such as {{c1::c-Myc, NF-KappaB, Jun}}

Which causes the condition {{c1::CML, can also cause ALL, CNL and AML}}

•Retrovirus used to introduce BCR-ABL in to mouse
•Mice developed a CML-like leukemia
•Mutant BCR-ABL (lacking kinase activity) did not induce leukemia

This is how Imatanib was found

KINASE THERAPY

Class of Kinase Inhibitor:Type I

MoA: {{c1::Competes for the substrate and binds in the ATP-binding pocket of the active conformation }}

Examples of Drugs:{{c1::Bosutinib, Cabozantinib, Ceritinib,
Crizotinib, Gefitinib, Pazopanib, Ruxolitinib, Vandetanib}}(8)



Class of Kinase Inhibitor:Type II

MoA: {{c1::Type II inhibitors bind to the DFG-Asp out protein kinase conformation, which corresponds to an inactive enzyme form}}

Examples of Drugs: {{c1:: Imatinib, Sorafenib, Axitinib, Nilotinib }}(4)


Class of Kinase Inhibitor: Type III (Allosteric Inhibitor)

MoA: {{c1::Occupy a site next to the ATP-binding pocket so that both ATP and the allosteric inhibitor can bind simultaneously to the protein.}}

Examples of Drugs:  {{c1::Trametinib, GnF2}} (2)



Class of Kinase Inhibitor:  Type IV (Substrate Directed Inhibitors)

MoA:  {{c1::Undergo a reversible interaction outside the ATP pocket and offer selectivity against targeted kinases}}

Examples of Drugs:  ONO12380
What is ONO12380 used for?
{{c1::binds an allosteric site on BCR-ABL and can be used to treated imatinib resistant CML.}}



Class of Kinase Inhibitor: Type V (Covalent Inhibitor)

MoA:{{c1::Bind covalently (irreversible)to their protein kinase target}}

Examples of Drugs: {{c1::Afatinib, Ibrutinib, HK1–272}}

The discovery that Rous sarcoma virus encoded an oncogenic gene that was a tyrosine kinase (v-src) first implicated kinases in the pathogenesis of cancer. Other human oncogenes were subsequently found to be kinases. Imatinib demonstrated the efficacy of targeting kinases in cancer and triggered a revolution in cancer therapy heralded the era of “targeted therapy”. 

What are the benefits of targeting oncogenic kinases?
{{c1::increased specificity, fewer adverse effects and dose limiting toxicity, culminating in  and better patient outcomes}}

Different Ways of Targeting Kinases

Such as Bevacizumab, which binds {{c1::VEGF}}, which stops it binding to the {{c1::VEGFR}} which inhibits {{c1::angiogenesis}} in {{c1::renal}} cancer

BRCA1/2 genes play roles in homologous recombination and contribute to DNA repair after damage. 

BRCA1/2 Mutations often lead to breast cancer. 

BRCA1/2 mutated cancer rely on {{c1::base excision repair}} to survive, which is mediated by {{c1::PARP}}. Therefore a treatment for cancers such as this is to inhibit {{c1::PARP}}, which means cancer DNA cannot be repaired, thus leading to cell death.

An example of a drug like this is {{c1::Olaparib}}

• Topoisomerase I is an enzyme that
{{c1::plays a role in unwinding DNA}} which
is required for DNA replication and
transcription

transcription, SN-38 induces
apoptosis

by {{c1::uridine diphosphate glucoronosyl

(bone marrow
suppression)}}

metabolized by gut
microbes so then its just SN-38 again, and gut cells are rapidly proliferating}}

Doxorubicin (Adriamycin)

An antibiotic derived from {{c1::Streptomyces}}

{{c1::• DNA synthesis ceases
• DNA double  strand breaks occur}}

Doxirubicin Semiquinone can react with {{c1::Fe3+}} to generate {{c1::free radicals}}.
{{c1::}}

Why does it effect cardiac tissue more than others?
{{c1::–because heart has lower levels of superoxide dismutase and catalase

Co-treatment with iron {{c1::chelators}} such as {{c1::dexrazoxane}} to limit redox cycling
which has been show to reduce cardiotoxicity from
{{c1::47}}% to {{c1::6}}%

Synthesis of Doxorubicin analogues that retain
the DNA interchelating activity of the drug but
do not redox cycle
– {{c1::Mitoxantrone}}, synthetic doxorubicin-like drug

Subclinical cardiac
damage in approx 25% of
children treated with
moderate doses

Angiogenesis and cancer

The supply of oxygen and nutrients to cells limits the size of a tumour to approximately a {{c1::millimetre}}.

How might a tumour get around this problem?
{{c1::Tumours can stimulate angiogenesis by releasing angiogenic factors or stimulating nearby normal cells to produce angiogenic factors}}

Tumours consist of many different types of cancer cells that all have different mutations

What meadiates apoptosis for cells that don't have a good enough O2 or nutrient supply.
{{c1::Caspase 3,6,7, through proteolytic cleavage of proteins}}

Is there anything the tumour can do to prevent this?
1.{{c1::angiogenesis}}
2.{{c1::BCL-2, oncogene that inactivates these caspases}}

What are some so-called 'angiogenic switches' (changes that causes a tumour to express angiogenic factors)?
{{c1::oxygen deprivation, although other stimuli such as inflammation, oncogenic mutations and mechanical stress may also play a role}}

What are some angiogenic factors?
{{c1::angiogenin, vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF), fibroblast growth factor (FGF), and transforming growth factor-β (TGF-β)}}(4)

What is the most prominent angiogenic factor?{{c1::VEGF, found in 60% of cells}}
